thread.title: Dimma’s slick plan to make Tigers ‘Great Again’
thread.title_full: Dimma’s slick plan to make Tigers ‘Great Again’

title: Dimma’s slick plan to make Tigers ‘Great Again’
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS ENTERING his eighth year as Tigers coach, Damien Hardwick suggested throughout pre-season that he wanted to ‘Make Richmond Great Again’. 
On Thursday night, he unveiled a fresh new game plan that might have the capability to do just that. 
While it remains to be seen just how ‘great’ the Tigers might actually prove to be in 2017 — a rebuilding Blues outfit is hardly the side finals contenders will be comparing themselves to — it was essential the club began the year doing something different. 
Things had become stale at Punt Road last year. The side’s brand of footy restricted its ability to attack and limited its players’ ability to express themselves on the field. 
Champion Data logged Richmond as having the second-highest amount of disposals in its defensive half in the league and the second-lowest metres gained per kick. 
The board — and certainly not the fans — perhaps wouldn’t have tolerated another year of dour footy. 
But they need not worry. Three goals inside the first eight minutes had many predicting a blowout, with a seven-goal opening term virtually enough to kill the match as a contest.

In the end, a 43-point margin of victory was comfortable and reflective of the routine nature in which the Tigers dismantled their opposition. 
Richmond consistently had more bodies around the ball and moved the footy swiftly and directly through the centre of the ground. 
This performance — a shadow of the listless efforts evident even in victory last season — was a sight for sore Tiger eyes. 
But the side’s style of footy wasn’t the only shiny new feature on display for Richmond on Thursday night. 
The club also unveiled four new recruits — three from rival sides and one from a previous draft — that left fans eager to see more. 
And while Dion Prestia and Toby Nankervis — arrivals via the trade table — both hit the scoreboard with early goals, it was Dan Butler who set Richmond alight. Richmond’s Jack Riewoldt celebrates his goal in the fourth quarter. Picture: George Salpigtidis Source: News Corp Australia 
The 67th pick in the 2014 national draft, Butler was one of few Tigers youngsters who couldn’t crack the senior side throughout the back-end of last year. 
But at the MCG, the 20-year-old was handed his chance — and made the most of it. 
With five disposals and two goals in the first quarter alone, Butler had already made himself a fan favourite of those residing in the Punt Road End. 
He was part of a relentless forward set-up that didn’t allow Carlton to create any sort of structurally sound defence. 
“It’s genuine forward pressure, not tokenism,” Fox Footy analyst David King said during the match. 
“(They’re producing) second and third efforts everywhere. It’s first class at the moment.” 
But this wasn’t all about youthful exuberance for the Tigers. 
Richmond blended their promising youngsters with a trio of handy recruits and a top-tier of talent that is good enough to mix it with the best. 
Dustin Martin more than likely has three Brownlow votes to his name as a result of his starring performance against the Blues, while Alex Rance is undoubtedly the best defender in the game. Dustin Martin starred on Thursday night. Picture: Wayne Ludbey Source: News Corp Australia 
When you consider the club also has a Brownlow Medalist and a two-time Coleman Medal winner in Trent Cotchin and Jack Riewoldt respectively, perhaps September isn’t out of the equation for the Tigers. 
It certainly isn’t if they retain a game plan as free flowing and attractive as the one they produced on Thursday night. 
Harder tests await the Tigers — next week’s fixture against Collingwood already looms as a defining game — but the draw has been kind to them. 
With only one match against a finals opponent from last year in their first five weeks, Richmond has a valuable chance to build momentum. And we all know how important that can be on the Tiger Train. 
For now, though, those supporters can simply enjoy a satisfying season-opening victory — an emotion they could barely muster throughout last season. 
Hardwick, meanwhile, can enjoy the fruits of an exhilarating new game plan. 
On Thursday night, his numbers at the opinion polls might even be higher than Donald Trump’s. And Richmond might be on its way to being ‘Great Again’.
